column1: Which C# namespace must be included to use classes such as DirectoryInfo, StreamReader, and StreamWriter?
column2: System.IO

column1: What C# property is used to retrieve the directory path from which the application is currently executing?
column2: AppDomain.CurrentDomain.BaseDirectory

column1: What is the primary purpose of the DirectoryInfo class in C#?
column2: To provide instance methods for creating, deleting, and moving directories.

column1: Which property of a DirectoryInfo object indicates whether the specified directory exists on the disk?
column2: Exists

column1: What method is called on a DirectoryInfo instance to create a new directory at the specified path?
column2: Create()

column1: Which method in the DirectoryInfo class is used to retrieve an array of files that match a specific extension?
column2: GetFiles()

column1: What search pattern string is passed to GetFiles() to ensure only text files are returned?
column2: *.txt

column1: What is the primary function of the StreamWriter class?
column2: To write text data to a file or a stream.

column1: What is the primary function of the StreamReader class?
column2: To read text data from a file or a stream.

column1: Why should StreamReader and StreamWriter be instantiated within a using statement?
column2: To ensure the file is closed and memory is freed automatically after use.

column1: Which method from the StreamReader class reads the entire content of a file into a single string variable?
column2: ReadToEnd()

column1: What does the dispose method do when called on a file handling object?
column2: It frees up the memory space previously occupied by that object.

column1: Which method in the Path class removes both the directory path and the file extension from a file path string?
column2: GetFileNameWithoutExtension()

column1: To handle runtime errors during file operations, code should be wrapped in a _____ structure.
column2: try-catch

column1: In the tutorial's example, what happens if no text files are present in the source directory?
column2: An information.txt file is created to notify the user.

column1: Under what condition does the tutorial's code delete the information.txt file?
column2: If it exists and there is more than one text file in the directory.

column1: What type of object is returned by the GetFiles() method of the DirectoryInfo class?
column2: FileInfo[] (an array of FileInfo objects)

column1: Why is the StreamWriter object passed as a parameter to methods like addTopHTML and buildHTMLBody?
column2: To allow multiple methods to write to the same output file stream.

column1: What is the benefit of using the static keyword for helper methods like buildHTMLBody in a console application's Main class?
column2: It allows the methods to be called directly from the static Main method.

column1: Which C# loop is used to traverse the array of text files returned by the GetFiles() method?
column2: foreach

column1: What is the purpose of the using statement in relation to the Close() method?
column2: It ensures the Close() method is called automatically when the code block finishes.

column1: In the context of HTML, what is a JavaScript library used for creating client-side interactive functionality like accordions?
column2: jQuery

column1: Which specific jQuery UI widget was used in the tutorial to display Wildcat information?
column2: Accordion widget

column1: What is the role of the HTMLOutputFile path variable in the tutorial's project?
column2: It stores the full path where the consolidated HTML file will be saved.

column1: What type of application project was created at the beginning of the tutorial?
column2: dotnet core console application

column1: How can you resolve a missing namespace error in Visual Studio using the mouse pointer?
column2: Hover over the red squiggly line and click "show potential fixes."

column1: What is the function of the rootPath variable in the Wildcat application?
column2: It stores the execution directory path to locate and create files relative to the application.

column1: In the tutorial, what is used to populate the headings of the jQuery UI accordion items?
column2: The name of each text file (without the extension).

column1: Why does the tutorial consolidate multiple text files into a single HTML file?
column2: To demonstrate reading from multiple sources and writing to a single output.

column1: What is the significance of the Close() method in file handling?
column2: It releases the file lock so other processes or methods can access the file.

column1: How is the final HTML output displayed to the user in the tutorial?
column2: The application launches the user's default web browser to open the file.

column1: What does an HTML file essentially consist of according to the tutorial's description?
column2: A text file containing markup that is interpreted by a web browser.

column1: What happens if you instantiate a StreamReader outside of a using block and do not call Close()?
column2: The file may remain locked and memory may not be released immediately.

column1: In the buildHTMLBody method, what is the third parameter used for?
column2: Passing the string content read from a text file.

column1: Why is it necessary to extract the filename without the extension when creating HTML headings?
column2: To provide a clean, readable title for the user interface.

column1: What is the purpose of the search pattern parameter in the DirectoryInfo.GetFiles method?
column2: To filter the returned files based on specific naming or extension criteria.

column1: In the tutorial, what is the default name given to the console application?
column2: wildcats application

column1: What is the role of the initializedSourceDirectory method in the provided code?
column2: To ensure the source directory exists and contains at least a default information file.

column1: Which C# keyword allows for the inclusion of external namespaces like System.IO at the top of a file?
column2: using

column1: What is the outcome of passing a directory path to the DirectoryInfo constructor?
column2: It initializes a new instance of the DirectoryInfo class for that specific path.

column1: How does the application determine the content of each accordion item?
column2: By reading the text from individual .txt files in the source directory.

column1: What is the specific subject matter used for the text files in the tutorial's example?
column2: Wildcats

column1: In the provided code, where is the catch block located in relation to the file handling logic?
column2: It follows the try block to handle any exceptions thrown during execution.

column1: What does the asterisk (*) signify in a search pattern like "*.txt"?
column2: It acts as a wildcard representing any sequence of characters.

column1: Which method is used to launch the default browser in C#?
column2: Process.Start()

column1: How does the tutorial describe the relationship between HTML and jQuery?
column2: jQuery is a JavaScript library used to add interactivity to the markup in an HTML file.

column1: What is the final step in the initializedSourceDirectory method?
column2: To return the DirectoryInfo object representing the source directory.

column1: Which variable name is used in the code to store the consolidated text before writing to the HTML file?
column2: content

column1: What is the benefit of downloading the code from GitHub as suggested in the tutorial?
column2: It saves time and avoids manual transcription errors from the video.

column1: What is the purpose of the addBottomHTML method in the Wildcat application?
column2: To write the closing HTML tags to finish the document structure.

column1: In the tutorial's loop, what happens to the content variable during each iteration?
column2: It is overwritten with the text from the next file in the directory.

column1: What determines the path of the source directory relative to the executable?
column2: The rootPath variable derived from the base directory.

column1: Why does the tutorial suggest pausing the video or using GitHub for the HTML/jQuery code?
column2: Because explaining HTML and jQuery is beyond the scope of the C# tutorial.

column1: What type of error is prevented by checking if a directory exists before creating it?
column2: An IOException or error from attempting to create an already existing folder.

column1: In the tutorial's logic, what does a single accordion item represent?
column2: The content of one individual text file.

column1: Which property of AppDomain is used to access the current domain's information?
column2: CurrentDomain

column1: How does the stream writer know which file to write to?
column2: The file path is passed as an argument to its constructor.

column1: What is the effect of the ReadToEnd() method on the stream's position?
column2: It moves the position to the very end of the stream.

column1: Which character separates the class name from its properties or methods in C#, such as in AppDomain.CurrentDomain?
column2: The dot (.) or period.

column1: In the tutorial, what is the next planned subject after handling text files?
column2: Handling binary files.

column1: What is the primary advantage of using a Console application for this tutorial?
column2: It provides a simple environment to focus on file handling logic without complex UI code.

column1: What is the purpose of the using directive at the top of a C# file?
column2: To allow the use of types in a namespace so you do not have to qualify them fully.

column1: In the tutorial, what specific wildcat was the first one added as a text file?
column2: Lion

column1: How does the application ensure that the HTML file is updated when new text files are added?
column2: The code traverses the directory and regenerates the HTML every time it runs.

column1: What is the relationship between DirectoryInfo and the local file system?
column2: DirectoryInfo acts as a wrapper that provides access to the physical directory on the disk.
